@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Which defeats the point of using an enumeration over an array; you would retrieve the values from either A.) populating a Map of the data, then getting it that way, or B.) using enum.values()

item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

What I said wasn’t aimed at you; even though I quoted you.

Anyway, it’s to create an object of data within the enumeration, for lack of better terms, an object is anything, so if I were to create an object[] I could within reason put anything inside of it.

[tt]new Object[] { 1, “hey yo”, 1.0000, true, false, ‘1’, new ClassName().method() }[/tt] etc and so forth.

item.title: [PI] Slayer
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:14, topic:458959”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=561867.msg4112042#msg4112042 date=1348612393]

wtf why are you casting integer rather than int?

Integer class != primitive type int

also, why are you all fucking enum hipsters? So what it looks cleaner does the same thing, personally I would use an array here too, as the array only holds one integer value and he would need multiple enums for this to even work properly.

(Or he could make the enum type int[][] which would totally defeat the purpose)

He could use an int for the difficulty, and I really do see how this can be used with 1 enum.

What? And, enlighten me don’t do it with a multidimensional array.
[/quote]

Okay, never mind. He would have to change a bit around.

But… this is what I would use for the enum

[code=java]public enum Difficulty {

EASY, MEDIUM, HARD

}

/**

  • The 1 - slayer level required

  • The 45 - max amount you can be assigned

  • 10.0 Slayer experience
    */
    public enum SlayerShit {
    SUMMONA{12983, new Object[][] {1, 45, 10.0}, Difficulty.EASY};

    private int id;
    private Object[][] data;
    private Difficulty difficulty;

    private SlayerShit(int id, Object[][] data, Difficulty difficulty) {
    this.id = id;
    this.data = data;
    this.difficulty = difficulty;
    }
    }[/code][/quote]
    Why in THE HELL would I make an individual object for each NPC?? Also, you do see what sets the difficulty right? It’s not per NPC… Combat level is also never taken into account… So many issues with what you’ve presented.

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Slayer
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:7, topic:458959”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=561867.msg4112001#msg4112001 date=1348610727]
Put it in an enum
[/quote]

[quote author=tyb97 link=topic=561867.msg4111850#msg4111850 date=1348602186]
That’s about the worst advice I’d ever been given. Firstly because an enum wouldn’t work here unless you made multiple, and you haven’t even given your reason for why I should use one.
[/quote][/quote]

An enum is neater. You can put the data into an undefined object and pull it out of there, such as the creature’s name, the required level, exp gained, etc.
I just used some of dementhium’s snippets to show an example

public double getXPAmount() { return Double.parseDouble(theEnum.data[taskId][4].toString()); }

public String getName() { return (String) theEnum.data[taskId][0]; }

public static SlayerTask random(Player player, Master master) { SlayerTask task = null; while (true) { int random = player.getRandom().nextInt(theEnum.data.length); int requiredLevel = (Integer) theEnum.data[random][1]; if (player.getSkills().getLevel(Skills.SLAYER) < requiredLevel) { continue; } if (random == 0 && !player.getRandom().nextBoolean()) { continue; } int minimum = (Integer) theEnum.data[random][2]; int maximum = (Integer) theEnum.data[random][3]; task = new SlayerTask(theEnum, random, Misc.random(minimum, maximum)); break; } return task; }

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Slayer
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Small slayer system I wrote up, kinda incomplete, you can take/give anyway you want. Posting in snippets because I don’t care to explain every piece of code.

This is the new slayer class:


package zerohour.model.players.skills;

import zerohour.model.players.Client;
import zerohour.util.Misc;

/**
 * The slayer class.
 * @author Tyler (Tyb97)
 *
 */
public class Slayer {

	public enum Difficulty {
		EASY, MEDIUM, HARD;
	}

	public static int[] belowThirty = { 1265, 1, 10, 123, 122, 282, 6217, 142,
			1712 };
	public static int[] belowSixty = { 193, 117, 941, 76, 1330, 145 };
	public static int[] belowNinety = { 111, 125, 49, 52 };
	public static int[] oneTwentySix = { 49, 21, 258, 50, 54, 53 };

	public static int[] amount = { 40, 60, 80 };

	public static int[] getLevel(final Client player) {
		if (player.combatLevel <= 30) {
			return belowThirty;
		} else if (player.combatLevel >= 31 && player.combatLevel <= 60) {
			return belowSixty;
		} else if (player.combatLevel >= 61 && player.combatLevel <= 90) {
			return belowNinety;
		} else if (player.combatLevel >= 91 && player.combatLevel <= 126) {
			return oneTwentySix;
		}
		return null;
	}

	public static Difficulty setDifficulty(final Client player) {
		if (player.taskAmount == amount[0]) {
			return Difficulty.EASY;
		} else if (player.taskAmount == amount[1]) {
			return Difficulty.MEDIUM;
		} else if (player.taskAmount == amount[2]) {
			return Difficulty.HARD;
		}
		return null;
	}

	public static void setTask(final Client player) {
		int random = 0;
		for (int i = 0; i < getLevel(c).length; i++) {
			random = i;
		}
		int variable = Misplayer.random(random);
		player.slayerTask = getLevel(c)[variable];
		player.taskAmount = amount[2];
		player.difficulty = setDifficulty(c);
	}
}

Replace your current appendSlayerExperience method located in the NPCHandler class with this.

	/**
	 * Slayer Experience
	 **/
	public void appendSlayerExperience(int i) {
		int npc = 0;
		Client c = (Client) Server.playerHandler.players[npcs[i].killedBy];
		if (c != null) {
			if (c.slayerTask == npcs[i].npcType) {
				c.taskAmount--;
				c.getPA().addSkillXP(npcs[i].MaxHP * Config.XP_RATE, 18);
				if (c.taskAmount <= 0) {
					c.sendMessage("You completed your easy slayer task!");
					c.getPA().addSkillXP((npcs[i].MaxHP * 8) * Config.XP_RATE, 18);
				}

			}
		}
	}

Yea, I know I didn’t doc anything, but most of the code is explanatory, if you have any questions just ask.

Read full topic
